oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Historical Curiosities versus Imperishable Text
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Mandell, Laura
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: poetry
18th-century literature
19th-century literature
literary history
popular literature
digital humanities
mediation
book history
print history
visual media
Poetry--Collections--History--18th century
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This short essay describes how the field of literary studies was bifurcated by print practices at the discipline’s inception into the historically mimetic and the aesthetically superior, the former kinds of poetry appearing in books of curiositites, and the latter occuring in disciplinary anthologies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: paj:The Journal of the Initiative for Digital Humanities, Media, and Culture; Vol. 1 No. 1 (2007): Inaugurating The Poetess Archive
